newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST - HK Newspaper Editorials - Oct 14.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK Newspaper Editorials - Oct 14.

text.p: NOTE: These are highlights of comments in the Hong Kong press. The views expressed are those of the newspapers quoted, and do not represent an editorial viewpoint of Reuters.

- With 260 days to go before the British colony reverts to China, editorials in the Hong Kong media on Monday concentrated on Chinese dissident Wang Xizhe who was reported to have fled to Hong Kong. they also tackled issues related to the territory's 1997 handover and the economy.
-- APPLE DAILY said it was outrageous that China had jailed Wang Xizhe's friend Wang Dan just because he took an overseas distance-learning course.
It said officials of Xinhua news agency said there were certain courses China did not allow its citizens to take, but it never said which ones.
Apple said that authoritarian rule in China made Hong Kong people worry about losing their freedom of expression after the handover.
The English-language HONGKONG STANDARD said it hoped Hong Kong would continue to give asylum to Chinese dissidents and help them go overseas after the handover.
It said this was an area where Hong Kong must emphasis the second part of the "One Country Two Systems" principle. It said Hong Kong's humanitarian treatment of dissidents should be respected.

The Beijing-funded TA KUNG PAO said the big rise on the Hang Seng Index showed Hong Kong people were optimistic and confident about the political and economic future of Hong Kong. It said China's economic development and its promise to maintain the prosperity of Hong Kong were an important factor behind the stock market surge.

-- SING TAO said China should insist that Japan dismantle the lighthouse on the diputed Diaoyu (Senkaku) Islands before holding any talks with Tokyo. It said that if Tokyo refused to do this, Beijing should take real actions to punish it.
